stem: A 9-month-old infant presents with sudden, episodic abdominal pain, drawing his knees to his chest. He passed a 'currant jelly' stool. Select the MOST appropriate actions and parameters to guide care.

actions.text: Prepare for an air or barium enema.
Offer clear liquids until pain subsides.
Attempt manual reduction of the mass via abdominal palpation.
Initiate IV fluids and maintain NPO status.

parameters.text: Assess for signs of bowel perforation (rigidity, fever).

rationale.correct: The infant's presentation (sudden abdominal pain, drawing knees to chest, currant jelly stool) is highly suggestive of intussusception. An air or barium enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic. Maintaining NPO status and initiating IV fluids are crucial for stabilization. Monitoring stool characteristics and signs of perforation are essential for assessing treatment effectiveness and potential complications.
rationale.incorrect: Offering clear liquids is inappropriate given the potential for bowel obstruction and the need for possible intervention. Manual reduction is contraindicated due to the risk of perforation. Head circumference is not relevant to this condition.
clinicalPearls: The passage of normal brown stool may indicate spontaneous reduction of the intussusception, requiring immediate notification of the provider.
A rigid abdomen or fever suggests bowel perforation, contraindicating an enema.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: A rigid abdomen or fever suggests bowel perforation, contraindicating an enema. Prioritize assessment for peritonitis.

mnemonic.title: INTUSSUSCEPTION
mnemonic.expansion:
I = Intussusception

Key Actions: Prepare for an air or barium enema; Initiate IV fluids and maintain NPO status
Key Monitoring: Characteristics of stool (consistency, color); Assess for signs of bowel perforation (rigidity, fever)

reviewUnits.heading: Intussusception â€” Pathophysiology & Recognition
reviewUnits.body: Telescoping bowel = Intussusception. Currant jelly stool (blood+mucus) is the classic sign. Air/Barium enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic (reduces the telescoping). Monitoring stool is key; if a normal brown stool occurs, it may have resolved spontaneously. The presence of a normal brown stool means the intussusception has likely reduced; notify the provider immediately as surgery/enema may be cancelled.

reviewUnits.heading: Testing Trap â€” Rigid abdomen
reviewUnits.body: If the abdomen becomes rigid or the fever spikes, it suggests perforation/peritonitis, and the enema should NOT be performed. Prioritize assessment for peritonitis.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Intussusception
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Prepare for an air or barium enema; Initiate IV fluids and maintain NPO status. Monitor: Characteristics of stool (consistency, color); Assess for signs of bowel perforation (rigidity, fever). The child must stay NPO until resolution to prevent further distension/complications. Manual reduction is contraindicated due to the risk of perforation. Head circumference is irrelevant.
